text: And she conceived again, and bare a son; and said, Now this time will my husband be joined unto me, because I have born him three sons: therefore was his name called Levi.
text_kjv: And she conceived again, and bare a son; and said, Now this time will my husband be joined unto me, because I have born him three sons: therefore was his name called Levi.
text_niv: Again she conceived, and when she gave birth to a son she said, “Now at last my husband will become attached to me, because I have borne him three sons.” So he was named Levi.
text_esv: Again she conceived and bore a son, and said, “Now this time my husband will be attached to me, because I have borne him three sons.” Therefore his name was called Levi.
text_nlt: Then she became pregnant a third time and gave birth to another son. He was named Levi, for she said, “Surely this time my husband will feel affection for me, since I have given him three sons!”
text_msg: She became pregnant yet again—another son. She said, "Now maybe my husband will connect with me—I've given him three sons!" That's why she named him Levi (Connect).
text_nasb: She conceived again and bore a son and said, 'Now this time my husband will become attached to me, because I have borne him three sons.' Therefore he was named Levi.
context: In ancient Near Eastern cultures, fertility was paramount. A woman's worth was often tied to her ability to produce offspring, especially sons, who could carry on the family name and inherit property. Rachel and Leah's rivalry for Jacob's affection was deeply intertwined with this cultural expectation. Having children secured a woman's position within the family and society, providing her with support in old age. The birth of sons was particularly significant for establishing lineage and ensuring the family's future prosperity. Names were not merely labels; they held profound meaning, often reflecting circumstances surrounding the birth or the parents' hopes and dreams for the child. The lack of birth control meant women were frequently pregnant. Polygamy, while not ideal, was practiced as a way to ensure offspring, particularly in situations of infertility or other circumstances that threatened the family line. Marriage customs were patriarchal, with the husband holding significant authority. The narrative in Genesis reflects these societal norms, portraying the intense pressure on women to bear children and the resulting competition and emotional complexities within a polygamous family. The constant comparison between the sisters, fueled by their desire for Jacob's favor and the societal value placed on fertility, highlights the challenges of their situation. The naming of the children provides clues into the women’s emotional states and their relationship with Jacob.
meaning: Leah's naming of Levi reveals a shift in her perspective. After bearing Reuben, she hoped for Jacob's attention, which didn't materialize fully. With Simeon, she acknowledged God's awareness of her unloved status. Levi's name, meaning 'joined' or 'attached,' expresses her hope that after three sons, Jacob would finally be bound to her in love and devotion. The name signifies a longing for relational reconciliation and a deeper connection with her husband. However, the text subtly hints at the futility of seeking fulfillment solely through human relationships. While children can bring joy and strengthen bonds, they cannot ultimately fill the void or guarantee lasting love. Theologically, this verse illustrates the human desire for belonging and acceptance. Leah's search for connection with Jacob mirrors humanity's search for connection with God. Just as Leah hoped Jacob would be 'joined' to her, God desires to be 'joined' to humanity through a covenant relationship. The inadequacy of Leah's attempts to secure Jacob's love through procreation foreshadows the limitations of relying solely on earthly means for lasting satisfaction. Ultimately, true and lasting fulfillment comes from a relationship with God, who loves unconditionally and desires to be intimately connected to us. The verse also foreshadows the future role of the Levites as the priestly tribe, dedicated to serving God and mediating between God and the people.
application: Genesis 29:34 offers several practical applications for modern believers. Firstly, it reminds us that our worth is not determined by our accomplishments or relationships. Leah sought validation through bearing sons, hoping to earn Jacob's love. In today's society, we often fall into the same trap, seeking validation through our careers, possessions, or social status. However, our true worth comes from being created in God's image and being loved unconditionally by Him. Secondly, the verse highlights the importance of seeking fulfillment in God, not in other people. Leah's disappointment reveals the danger of placing unrealistic expectations on relationships. While healthy relationships are important, they cannot be the sole source of our happiness or sense of self-worth. Instead, we should cultivate a deep and personal relationship with God, who can provide us with the love, acceptance, and purpose we crave. Thirdly, it prompts us to examine our own motivations in relationships. Are we seeking to give and serve, or are we trying to manipulate or control others to get our needs met? Healthy relationships are built on mutual respect, trust, and selfless love. Fourthly, it encourages us to practice empathy and compassion towards others, especially those who may be struggling with feelings of loneliness, insecurity, or inadequacy. Everyone longs to be loved and accepted, and we can be instruments of God's love by extending grace and understanding to those around us. Finally, it reminds us that God sees our struggles and hears our cries. Like Leah, we can bring our pain, disappointment, and desires to God in prayer, trusting that He will comfort us and guide us towards His perfect plan for our lives.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you today feeling like Leah, longing for connection and acceptance. I confess that I often seek validation in the wrong places, in achievements, possessions, and the approval of others. Forgive me for placing my worth on these fleeting things. Help me to remember that my true worth comes from being your beloved child. Fill the voids in my heart with your unconditional love. Teach me to find my fulfillment in you, not in other people. Grant me wisdom to build healthy relationships, based on mutual respect and selfless love. Help me to see others through your eyes, with empathy and compassion. Lord, I bring my longings and disappointments to you. Hear my cries, and comfort me with your presence. Guide me towards your perfect plan for my life, a plan filled with hope, purpose, and lasting joy. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: In ancient societies, children, particularly sons, were vital for continuing the family lineage, ensuring economic stability, and providing support in old age. Fertility was seen as a blessing from God, and barrenness was often considered a curse. Large families were a sign of prosperity and strength.

faqs.answer: Levi's name, meaning 'joined' or 'attached,' reveals Leah's deep desire for a closer relationship with her husband, Jacob. After bearing her first two sons, she hoped that the third son would finally secure his affection and devotion, bringing them closer together.
